title: What is the history of Chinese porcelain? - Quora

response.answer_text: China is the birthplace of porcelain, and the invention of porcelain is one of China’s biggest contributions to world civilization. The porcelain made in China is exquisite and beautiful. Some of the them are gorgeous, some are plain, and some are simple, all of them featured with Chinese style. Starting from gray pottery, black pottery, red pottery, painted pottery, white pottery and glazed hard pottery, porcelain is an indispensable part of people’s life. This is just the beginning of the development of porcelain. Up to Sui dynasty, celadon was made, and white porcelain had developed a lot. Tang dynasty, a watershed between pottery and porcelain, appeared the real porcelain, before which, the texture of pottery is fragile. Yue kiln and Xing kiln also appeared at that time. In the period of Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms, Yue kiln became the royal warrant vessels, during which the color of celeste appeared. In Song dynasty, the top five famous kiln, Ding kiln, Ru kiln, Guan kiln, Ge kiln, Jun kiln, have elegant and beautiful appearance, which are far more better than before. In Ming dynasty and Qing dynasty, porcelain came in a great many varieties, such as five color, clashing color, which were the foundation of painted porcelain afterwards. Even the famous Japanese Imari porcelain developed from the clashing porcelain at this period. Besides, there were also yellow color with red background, yellow color with blue background, blue and white color with yellow background, etc. No matter how will the porcelain changes, it is always the proud of our nation.

Chinese Porcelain | Porcelain History | Cíqì  Facts about Porcelain China, as one of the world's four countries of great ancient civilizations, has made outstanding contributions to the progress and development of human society, in which the invention and development of ceramics (陶瓷 [táo cí]) are of special significance. China is the hometown of porcelain (瓷器 [cí qì]), and Chinese porcelain is highly commended for its extremely high practicality and artistry all over the world. Chinese porcelain, as one of the earliest works of art introduced into the western countries by the silk road (丝绸之路 [sī chóu zhī lù]), is known for its delicate texture, beautiful color, and exquisite sculpture. In the course of its development, Chinese porcelain was made in the form of many kinds of items such as cups, tea sets, bowls, incense burners, vases, etc., which rapidly became a necessity of daily life in the middle and upper classes.Porcelain is made from chinastone, kaolin, quartz, and many other materials, with the glassy glaze or painting on the appearance. The porcelain is made by firing at high temperature (1280–1400 ℃) in the kiln. And the glaze color on the porcelain surface will vary with the temperature, which gives rise to the diversity of Chinese porcelain. Porcelain is the treasure of Chinese civilization. History of Chinese Porcelain The predecessor of Chinese porcelain was the primitive celadon (青瓷 [qīng cí]) , which was the product of the transition from pottery to porcelain. The earliest primitive celadon in China was found at the Dongxiafeng cultural relic in Xia county, Shanxi province. The primitive celadon was made in Xia dynasy (2070 BC–1600 BC) about 4,200 years ago. The primitive celadon was widely distributed in China and was found in the yellow river, the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River and the south area of China. With the development of Chinese porcelain, more and more kinds of porcelain became to emerge. By the Eastern Han dynasty period (206 BC–220 AD), the primitive celadon had developed into porcelain. After the emergence of primitive celadon from the Shang dynasty (1600 BC–1046 BC) to the Eastern Han dynasty, Chinese porcelain had experienced 1600–1700 years of changes and development and entered a new era. During the Tang dynasty (618–906 CE), the development of porcelain was becoming more and more prosperous. It developed into two major porcelain systems, Celadon and white porcelain of monochrome glaze. The decorative techniques such as engraving, scratching, printing, decals, carving and hollowing appeared. The white porcelain from Xing kiln in Hebei Province was known for its white color and hardness, which was very popular in the west. The Yue kiln of Zhejiang Province was also well known for its beautiful celadon.In the Song dynasty (960–1279), new improvements was made in the aspects of quality, glaze and manufacturing skills. It was an important stage for the development of porcelain in China. Ru kiln (汝窑 [rǔ yáo]) , Ding kiln (定窑 [dìng yáo]) , Ge kiln (哥窑 [gē yáo]) , Jun kiln (钧窖 [jūn jiào]) , and the official kilns ( 官窑 [guān yáo]) were the representative kilns at that time. (Ru kiln was the most famous one of the five kilns in the Song dynasty. It added treasured agate into glaze, making the color and texture unique compared to the jade. Ding kiln was famous for its white porcelain with the delicate texture and little pink in white glaze. Porcelain of Jun kiln was made for the royal family that each porcelain had its own unique decorative patterns and colors.In the Yuan dynasty (1271–1368), the blue and white porcelain (青花瓷 [qīng huā cí]) became the mainstream. Jingdezhen (景德镇 [jǐng dé zhèn]) in Jiangxi province added cobalt on the process of making porcelain and invented the blue and white porcelain, which became an imperial porcelain production center in that period. More and more porcelains were exported to other countries through the silk road. In the Song danasty and Yuan dynasty, the single-color glaze was the main type of porcelain.In the Ming dynasty (1368–1644), multicolor glaze and some other colorful glazes gradually developed and became popular. The diversification of porcelain glaze in Ming dynasty marked the continuous improvement of China's porcelain making techniques.Until the Qing dynasty (1644–1912), personalized porcelain became popular among foreigners during the reign of emperor Kangxi (1653–1722).
